More pleas'd with ſuch a Sea than Meat and Drink.

sp.speaker: Povi.
sp.l: Came think no more of Rebels, but of things
Concerning Princes, Emperours, and Kings,
The time draws nigh, wherein you muſt prepare,
To furniſh Albion with a Lawful Heir.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: I've bore this Pillow, ſix months on my Womb,
And muſt do ſo, for three Months yet to come:
And ſince my Time of Labour doth draw nigh,
I muſt augment, and ſet the Pillow high;
Rip up the Prince, and put ſome Cotton in,
He will not cry altho you prick his Skin.
sp.stage: Pulleth the Pillow, from her Womb, and giveth it to the Lady, who stuffeth it with a pound of Cotton. Pointing at Petrus.
sp.l: Call in the Midwife, and Petrona too,
I'll take advice of them how I ſhall do.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.l: This greaſy Pillow is a naſty thing,
It ne're will be a good Prince nor a King.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Leave off to jeſt, 'tis not a fitting time
Of that which known, would prove a deadly crime.

div.stage: Enter Midwife, Petrona big with Child, and Petrus Impoſtor.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: You know Petrona that I do deſign,
To add an Heir unto the Royal line;
Which muſt be done by Hocus means, when I
Shall counterfeit a Labour, and Out-cry,
You muſt be there, and privately convey
Your child to me if that it be a Boy,
When you are brought to Bed; and till you be,
I'll grunt and groan, that none may queſtion me.
You are of my Religion you know how,
That this will all the Hereticks o'rethrow;
That live in Albun, For their Prince ſhall be,
Prought up at Rome, and train'd in Popery.
Now what ſhall I give for your Child, if it
Should prove a Boy, and all my projects hit.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Five thouſand pound the matter will decide,
My Child's a Boy, it lyes in the right ſide.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Five thouſand pound to make your Son a King!
This is a more than ordinary thing;
But will not ſtand what you have ſaid to do,
If to a conſtant ſecrecy you'll vow.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I, by our Lady's Girdle and her Garter,
Rather than ſpeak one word will dye a Martyr.

sp.speaker: Petrus.
sp.l: That will not do; but whiſpering to prevent,
On what you ſay, you's take the Sacrament.

sp.speaker: Papiſſa.
sp.l: Let it be ſo; for then we'll have ſome ground,
Without delay, to pay five thouſand Pound.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: But what if it ſhould prove a Girl, when ſhe
Hath got the Sum of Money? where are we?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Tho it prove ſo, I ſhall have others there,
And ſurely one will ſerve me for an Heir.
There is no need the Money to reſtore;
For Albion ſhall ſupply me ſtill with more,
'Tis for the uſe of it, I lay it out,
And it ſhall buy me too a Baby-clout,

sp.speaker: Povi.
sp.l: Here is your Prince, whom you ſo much adore,
'Tis weightier by a pound, than 'twas before,

div.stage: Povioena giveth back the Pillow to the Queen.
Queen Papiſſa taketh the pillow, and layeth it on her Belly, from whence ſhe had taken it.

sp.speaker: Midw.
sp.p: It is too low,

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: Make it like mine.

sp.speaker: Petrus.
sp.p: Set it higher, thus.

sp.speaker: Midw.
sp.p: Now it is too high.

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.p: Pull it a little to the right ſide.

sp.speaker: Petrus.
sp.p: Let it be ſo,

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Now it is right.
I hope in time, to bring forth this my Son,
And end my Labour, e're it be begun.

div.stage: Enter Romanus.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: What Intrigues here of ſelf-confounding Wit,
That's good for all, and yet for nothing fit.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Rouſe up old Boy, altho thy vigour fails,
I will preſent thee with a —

div.stage: Clappeth her hand on her Belly.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: That Prince will be my more than mor tal Foe,
And prove e're many years my overthrow.
For when the project is found out I ſhall,
With Shame, receive a ſad and diſmal Fall.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: He ſhall be your adopted Son, and Reign
As much as he had been by Nature mine:
He is your artificial Child, and ſhall,
In ſpite of all oppoſers, have the Wall.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I have a Son, my Husband never got,
Yet he's he the Father, for he doubts it not:
Believe he's yours, and your Son that's bought,
Will have, for whom, in Bed, you never wrought.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: To give three Kingdoms, one was never known,
Unto a Beggar's Child to cheat his own.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: I'll have it ſo, and if you dare deny;
My Will's a Law, and none ſhall ask me why.

sp.speaker: Petrus.
sp.l: Great Sir, You promiſed once to reſtore
The Church of Rome, as ſhe hath been before.
This is the way, and only this will do,
A Popiſh Prince will make three Nations bow.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Monſter of Dragons, muſt I turn, and be
An ancient Fop of Inhumanity:
Let it be ſo, you ſhall have my conſent,
But blame me not, when after you repent.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You muſt appoint a ſolemn day of thanks,
To pray to Heaven, to cover all our pranks;
And write to Rome, to ſave us from the Lurch,
To ſing Te Deum, in St. Marry's Church.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Were I with Child, I ſhould fear, that the prayer
Of Proteſtants, ſhould make me loſe mine Heir.
But now Papiſſa all their power defies,
Let them mock Heaven, to blind their own eyes.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I'll call the Clergy, and appoint a Day
Of Faſt, whereon the Hereticks may pray,
That you may not miſcarry, but enjoy
A Popiſh Prince, their Pulpits to deſtroy.

div.stage: Exit Roman.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Now I am pleas'd, for 'tis a famous thing,
To be the mother of a potent King.
Come let us a play a Game at Cards for I,
Am not affraid that I'll in Child-birth dye.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: We'll play at Beaſt, for by our wit we ſhall,
Confound our Foes, and make them all to fall:
Perſwading old Romanus to a thing,
That's far below the Candour of a King.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: What ſhall we play for?

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Fifty pound a Game.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: My Duce againſt your Ace.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Out fie ſhame,
That you, who muſt forgive me all my Sin,
Should proffer thus my Gravity to win.

div.stage: He ſhuffleth and dealeth the Cards, and turneth up a Pick Trump.

sp.speaker: Petrus.
sp.p: Come, Picks are Trumph.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Here is a Royal King.

div.stage: She playeth the King of Hearts.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Here I'm above him.

div.stage: Petrus playeth the Knave above him.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: That's an unjuſt thing.
A royal Prince of his right to bereave,
sp.stage: Papiſſa ſtoppeth him from taking the Trick.
sp.l: Eclips'd by any Varlet, Clown, or Knave.
It will not do, but here am I my ſelf.

div.stage: [playeth the Q. of Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: And here am I above you.

div.stage: Petrus playeth the Knave above the Queen.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: This is a thing that I will not allow,
I try'd the Trick, and know it will not do.
Here is my Ace of Clubs.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sure I'll have that.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Pray hold your hand, and tell me firſt for what.

div.stage: Stoppeth him from taking the Trick.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Here is my Trea of Picks, and that is Trumps.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.p: Pray take it then.

div.stage:
Enter Povioena in haſte, and whiſpereth Queen Papiſſa in the ear,
telling her that Six of the Nine women with Child, were in Labour,
deſiring her, in all haſte, to take her Labour too, and
make choice of a Prince, or Royal Heir. Exeunt Papiſſa & Povioena.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I am the wit of Europe, and what's more,
The man that muſt the Church of Rome reſtore:
I can out-wit the wiſe, in every thing,
And by the Noſe I lead Great Albion's King.
My policy the Queen with Child begot,
Now I'm a hatching of a Powder-plot,
That will deſtroy the Hereticks, and thoſe
That ſtrive the Roman Intereſt to oppoſe.

div.stage: Enter Romanus, Alberlo, Cancellarius, and Calamus.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: How now? doſt thou thus talk unto thy ſelf?
Like ſome Hob-Gobbling Ghoſt or Fairy-Elf.
Doſt thou invoke the Furies, from below,
To work thy King Romanus overthrow?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The Queen crys out; and I but pray that ſhe,
The Mother of a Royal Prince may be;
A Prince that may on Hereticks paſs Doom,
And make the Univerſe ſubmit to Rome.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Cry out! how ſo? methinks you're mad indeed,
Such fooliſh Fancies in your Brains to breed:
I am aſham'd ſuch idle talk to hear,
For 'tis too ſoon, I'm ſure by half a year.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: She is in Labour, for I heard her cry,
sp.stage: Wipeth his eyes as he were crying.
sp.l: And I'm afraid that Queen Papiſſa dye.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Good time, with eaſy Labour, like a Nun,
May ſhe enjoy, and for her pains a Son.

sp.speaker: Canc.
sp.l: A Son that may this ſtubborn Nation bring
In more ſubjection, to a potent King.

div.stage: The cry of a woman in Labour is heard without.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I heard a cry, and judge that it may be,
The Queen in Labour—

div.stage: All hearken, but hear nothing.
Enter Two Biſhops in Surplices.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Pray who comes here? Two Biſhops? get you gone,
I'm buſie now, but you may come anon.

sp.speaker: Biſh.
sp.l: We hear the Queen's in Labour, therefore we
Should in her privy Chamber preſent be,
That if ſhe have a Son we may declare,
Him Albion's Royal, True and Lawful Heir.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Seditious Apes, you Trumpeters of Treaſon,
Be gone, or elſe I'll ſend you both to Priſon.
What's your concernment? what ſhould you declare?
I'm old enough to look to my true Heir.

div.stage: Exeunt Biſhops.
Enter Midwife, bearing a Basket, with a naked Baby in it.

sp.speaker: Midwife.
sp.l: Great Sir, I'm come before your eyes to bring,
A Royal Prince, that may in time, be King
sp.stage: [To King Romanus, whilſt Alberlo standeth at a diſtance.
sp.l: Of theſe three Nations, pious, wiſe and juſt;
After you're Dead, and are diſſolv'd in duſt.
Come welcome him into the world, and ſee
If e're you knew a finer Child than he.

div.stage: Preſenteth her Basket.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: It is a pretty Child, take him away.

sp.speaker: Midw.
sp.p: There never was a finer made of clay.

sp.speaker: Canc.
sp.p: It is a Girl, I vow, pray Midwife look.

sp.speaker: Midw.
sp.l: I from the number, have the wrong Child took,
But will bring in another.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: Pray thee do.

sp.speaker: Midw.
sp.p: I can another, and another too:

div.stage: [Exit Midwife.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Theſe fooliſh women are for nothing fit,
They will betray the projects of our wit.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I'd rather give ten thouſand pound, in Gold,
Than it were known, the Child were bought and ſold.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Your words are dark, I know not what you mean.
Be bought and ſold, and children of the Queen.

sp.speaker: Canc.
sp.l: He only talks of things, he knows not what,
Of Monks and Friars, and Nuns, and this and that.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Alberlo, prithee for an hour be gone,
We have a private project to be done.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How e're ſo private, you may tell it me,
But ſcorn that I a burden now ſhould be.

div.stage: Exit Alber.
Enter Midwife bearing two Baskets.

sp.speaker: Midw.
sp.l: Here are two Children, take your choice and ſee,
Which Child is fit a royal Prince to be.

div.stage: They take the two Children out of the Basket, and hand them from one to another.

sp.speaker: Canc.
sp.p: This is the fatteſt.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.p: And the faireſt too.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: We'll ſeek no other, for the ſame will do.
Let every Roman Catholick now ſing
In Expectation of a Popiſh King,
Who will the Church of Rome again renew,
And all the ſtiff-neck'd Hereticks ſubdue.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Call in the Biſhops, now, that they may ſee,
My Lawful Heir, and Royal Progeny.

div.stage: Exit Calam.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Great Sir, Will you admit them to behold
Young Innocent? and dare they be ſo bold,
With eyes and breath Heretick to prophane
The Prince that will reſtore our Church again:
We of their company ſtand not in need,
Much leſs to ſee, or touch the Royal Seed.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Impoſtor, ſhould I counſell'd be by you,
I ſhould my ſelf and all that's mine undo;
I might look great a while, but muſt confeſs,
I quickly ſhould be Crown, and Kingdomleſs.
You hatch'd the Prince, within your fiery Brain,
And I'm afraid the plot will prove in vain.

sp.speaker: Canc.
sp.l: There is no danger, and you need not fear,
If you'll conceal all from the Subjects ear.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The Child is yours, tho Proteſtants ſhould prate,
From Clown to Prince, he's Tranſubſtantiate.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I wiſh it prove ſo, and that no man may,
My Hocus Tricks, and juggling Acts betray.

div.stage: Enter two Biſhops, Manlius, and Oxonius, with Calamus Tremeb.

sp.speaker: Manl.
sp.l: May't pleaſe your Majeſty, I hear the Queen
Hath theſe two Weeks, in cruel Labour been;
And now brought forth a Son, as we did pray,
When we, at Chriſtmas laſt, kept Holy day,

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I have a Son that is both plump and fair,
And hope will prove Great Albion's Lawful Heir.

div.stage: Enter Papiſſa, Povioena, and the Midwife, bearing the young Prince.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: My wife you're welcome to the world again,
You have not ſpent your Labour now in vain.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: I was ſo deadly ſick, I tell no ſtory,
That I was near the Gates of Purgatory.
sp.stage: The King ſaluteth his Queen Papiſſa, and every one kiſſeth her Hand round.
sp.l: Here is your Royal Heir which I did bring,
sp.stage: Taketh the Child from the Midwife, and giveth it to the King.
sp.l: From Death's dark door, to be Great Albion's King.
Come hug and hand him all, from one another,
I ſhall not run the hazard of another.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: This Birth ſtrikes Rebels blind, turns to deſpair,
sp.stage: Manlius taketh him in his Arms.
sp.l: Their hopes of Conteſt for a Royal Heir.
Sedition ſinks down dead, and every Traytor
Metamorphos'd is to another creature.
Rebellion puts on black, and ſadly crys,
And Turn-coat Treaſon deſperately dies.

sp.speaker: Oxon.
sp.l: Then may he live, and wear his Father's Crown;
sp.stage: Oxonius taketh the Prince in his Arms.
sp.l: And gain his Kingdom's Honour and Renown.
Like Solomon, for wiſdom let him be,
And good Joſiah for true piety;
Not furious, fierce, but merciful and kind;
Like Jonathan, in conſtancy of mind:
Like Moſes meek, Majeſtick in his word,
To ſway the Scepter, and unſheath the Sword;
To cheriſh Subjects, and promote the good,
To cut off Rebels, and caſt down the proud.
That all his Subjects may (like Flowers in May)
With peace and plenty, flouriſh in his day.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Theſe are two honeſt Hereticks, and I
Will ſtill be mindful of their Loyalty.

div.stage: Enter Meſſenger in haſte.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: Great Sir, I'm come in haſte, to let you know,
Of a more fierce and powerful Weſtern Foe.
The Golden Prince from Belgium is come o're,
With fifty Sail of Ships, and on our ſhore
Hath landed Twenty thouſand men in Arms,
Which do ſurprize us with their freſh alarms.
Your Peers and Subjects joyn with him apace,
And every oppoſition gives him place.
He doth affirm and ſolemnly declare,
The Royal Prince to be no Lawful Heir,
But a dark Pillow-Prince, hatch'd in the night
By Popiſh pranks, to cheat him of his right.
The groaning Nation, and the Subjects crys,
The Widows Tears, and Orphans weeping eyes,
Your baniſh'd Subjects, Liberties, and Laws,
And his own right make up a Lawful Cauſe,
Of bloody War; Therefore he vows to fight
Againſt your Popiſh Crew, for his own right.
Your Souldiers, Subjects, Peers, and all accoſt
His coming in, and joyn unto his Hoſt,
Which call themſelves the Safe-guard of the Nation;
And to confirm all, here's his Declaration.

div.stage: He giveth Romanus a paper, which he looketh a little on.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: I will make haſte, to muſter all my Hoſt;
I'll fight in perſon, e're my Crown be loſt.
Go Meſſenger, in haſte, and view the Force
Of all the Prince's Army, Foot and Horſe.
And, when you have done ſo, return to me,
And for your pains, you ſhall rewarded be,
This is the Fruit of your confounded pranks,
For which I owe the old Impoſtor thanks,
And muſt confeſs, not without provocation,
That now the Prince invaded hath the Nation.

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I oft times told thee what would be the end
Of all the projects which thou didſt intend;
And hadſt thou taken but advice of me,
Thou of this Scene of Sorrow hadſt been free;
Which, now, is like to work thy fatal fall,
And, in a moment, to undo us all.

sp.speaker: Canc.
sp.l: Promotion is the Curſe of men, and I
Am ſo aſtoniſh'd that I fear to dye.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I'm ſo caſt down and terrify'd in mind,
That I'm affraid a Remedy to find.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: Shall I who have in ſo great ſplender been,
Preferr'd to be Great Albion's Royal Queen,
Be forc'd to live in ſhame, and great diſdain,
And ſteer my courſe to Italy again.
I can but wring my hands, and ſtamp and ſtare,
And, half diſtracted, tear my curled hair.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And why ſo much affraid? I queſtion not
To ſerve him as I did the R—
I'll go, with ſpeed, an army to provide,
Which will all quarrels with the Sword decide:

sp.speaker: Calam.
sp.l: I will, in ſpite of every former Crime,
Turn to a State Hermophrodite of Time.
I'll whine and wheedle, ſide with every thing,
That will my projects to perfection bring:
Yet, come what will, I ſhall until I dye
Be ſure to ſerve your Soveraign Majeſty.

div.stage: Exit Calamus.

sp.speaker: Canc.
sp.l: I've ſo behav'd my ſelf, that I ſhall dye,
If catch'd; and now can neither ſtay or fly;
I am ſo terrify'd and ſtung whith Guilt
Of Villanies, and Blood that I have ſpilt:
My Brains diſtracted, Fear doth me poſſeſs,
My Joynts do tremble for my Wickedneſs.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.l: I will return to Rome, from whence I came,
And ſtrive to ſet all Europe in a flame,
Yet Albion, tho I ſhould contrive a Plot,
Will ſlight my Wits, and find an Antidote.

div.stage: Enter Meſſenger in haſte.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: I have ſurvey'd and view'd the Weſtern Hoſt,
And now three Kingdoms, with your Crowns, are loſt.
Your Guards, with all your Military Force,
Of Men and Arms, of Infantry and Horſe,
Have joyn'd themſelves unto your mortal Foes,
Whoſe power the Church of Rome cannot oppoſe.
The War is ended, e're it be begun,
And there is now no Remedy but, Run.
sp.stage: Drums beat and Trumpets ſound without.
sp.l: The Enemy's at hand, therefore be gone,
Preſerve your ſelf, if you ſhould loſe your Throne.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: He'll take the projects, which the Romiſh Crew
Have, by their Conjurations, forc'd me to.
Now I muſt ſteer my Courſe, I know not where,
And all is long of this your Royal Heir.

sp.speaker: Pap.
sp.l: I'll ſtrait to Gallia, and uſe all my Arts,
Wherewith I uſe to conquer greateſt Hearts;
I'll try them all, and ſee what power I have,
To make that Generous Monarch's heart my Slave.
And if in this the Fates will be but kind,
As with this Prince I may ſuch favour find,
To grant but power ſufficient to ſubdue
This Fortunate, and too Victorious Foe;
They quickly then ſhall my reſentments ſee,
And find what 'tis to injure mighty me.
I'll bring ſuch Monſters, as ſhall make a Flood
Of Engliſh Hereticks, and Rebels Blood.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: May Heav'n be kind, and your endeavours bleſs,
Whilſt I invoke the Gods for your ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: When your kind Fate to Gallia ſhall you bring,
My beſt Reſpects to the Moſt Chriſtian King;
Tell him he little doth deſerve that Name;
And alſo what a moſt prodigious ſhame
'Twill be, unto the Faith he doth profeſs,
If he my Grievances don't ſoon redreſs:
I, who to th' brink of wretchedneis am come,
And all for being true to th' Church of Rome.
The Enemy's at hand, Papiſſa, go,
And get but force to oppoſe this Mighty Foe,
We'll enter Albion, and ſuch ſpoil will make
Shall cauſe the proudeſt of their hearts to ake;
We then ſhall our Revenge moſt ſweetly taſte,
We'll Ravage, Plunder, Burn, Deſtroy, lay Waſte,
And not a Rebel leave alive at laſt.

div.stage: The Queen tyeth the Prince on Father Petrus's back, and all run out in great haſte.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: THe Banquet's o're, and we have fed your ſenſes
With Blood & Wounds, & Catholick pretences.
We ſhew you, in this more than ſumptuous Feaſt,
The Riſe and Downfal of the Roman Beaſt.
With Diſhes we your Appetite have fed,
Such as Aſhuerus Table never had,
When Symmachus had ſet before his eye
A Fiſhes head, affrighted, he did fly
From it: For he did take it for the head
Of Theodorick, whom he murdered:
Even ſo this Feaſt, preſented to your eye,
Was Murther, Blood-ſhed and Phlebotomy;
With Pride, Promotion, Madneſs, and what not,
That can outdo a Super-treaſon Plot.
Yet, as in Summer, every Hony-Bee
Sucks ſweet from every object which they ſee,
The wiſe and prudent may reap what is good,
From this our Feaſt, and after chew the Cud;
And attribute the end of humane things
To Providence, and not to Powerful Kings.
But leſt your Diſhes of Revenge and Spite.
Should not have reliſh'd with each appetite,
To pleaſe you, we a Voider did afford,
That did remove your Diſhes by the Sword;
A Potent, Pious Prince, who by his Might,
Reſtor'd three Kingdoms to their former Right.
In fine then, Gentlemen, you're welcome all;
Our will is good, although the Feaſt be ſmall:
And if by chance we meet another day,
We'll treat you with a more delicious Play.
